test_generations: Mukesh Ambani is a well-known business magnate in India, born on April 19, 1957, in Aden, Yemen. He is the chairman and managing director of Reliance Industries Limited (RIL), a Fortune Global 500 company and India's largest private sector enterprise. Ambani's business interests are diverse and include oil and gas exploration, petrochemicals, textiles, telecommunications, and retail. Under his leadership, Reliance Industries has transformed into a multinational conglomerate with a global presence in more than 30 countries. He is also known for his philanthropic efforts through the Reliance Foundation, which focuses on education, healthcare, and rural development.

Massimo Vignelli is a renowned Italian graphic designer and typographer, born in Milan, Italy, on November 10, 1931. After studying at the Brera Academy of Fine Arts in Milan, he moved to New York City in 1956, where he worked for various design studios before establishing his own firm, Vignelli Associates, in 1965. Throughout his career, Vignelli has created iconic designs for numerous clients, including American Airlines, Bloomingdale's, and the New York City subway system. He is known for his minimalist and functional approach to design, which has had a significant influence on modern graphic design. He has received numerous awards and recognition for his work, including the AIGA Gold Medal in 1995 and the Cooper Hewitt National Design Award in 2006.

Farrokh Bulsara, better known as Freddie Mercury, was a British musician and lead vocalist of the rock band Queen. Born in Zanzibar to Parsi parents from India, Mercury grew up in India and moved to England with his family at the age of 17. He began his music career in the late 1960s, performing in bands such as Ibex and Wreckage before co-founding Queen in 1970. Known for his powerful voice, flamboyant stage presence, and impressive vocal range, Mercury became one of rock music's greatest frontmen, helping to define the sound and image of Queen. He died in 1991 due to complications from AIDS.

Socrates (469/470 BCE - 399 BCE) was a Greek philosopher who is widely regarded as one of the founders of Western philosophy. He was born in Athens, Greece to a family of sculptors. Socrates did not write any books or papers, but his ideas and dialogues were preserved by his students, most notably Plato. He believed that knowledge could only be acquired through self-examination and questioning, and that the unexamined life is not worth living. His philosophy focused on ethics, morality, and the nature of reality. He died in Athens, Greece after being sentenced to death by a court for "corrupting the youth" of Athens.

Elie Wiesel was a Romanian-born Jewish writer, professor, political activist, and Nobel laureate. Born on September 30, 1928, in Sighet, Hungary (now Romania), Wiesel survived the Auschwitz and Buchenwald concentration camps during the Holocaust. After the war, he became a prominent voice for human rights and social justice, writing numerous books, including "Night," which chronicles his experiences in the concentration camps. Wiesel won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986 and was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1993. He passed away on July 2, 2016, at the age of 87.

Robin Williams was born in Chicago, Illinois, on July 21, 1951, to Robert Fitzgerald Williams and Laurie McLaurin. His father was a Ford Motor Company executive, and his mother was a former model. Williams grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area and developed an early interest in comedy and acting. After attending Juilliard, he rose to fame in the 1970s and 1980s with his rapid-fire wit and physical humor. Williams gained international recognition for his breakthrough roles in the hit films "Good Morning, Vietnam" (1987) and "Dead Poets Society" (1989), for which he received Academy Award nominations. Throughout his career, he won numerous accolades for his work on stage, screen, and television, including four Golden Globes and two Emmy Awards. On August 11, 2014, Williams was found unresponsive in his home near San Francisco and was pronounced dead at the age of 6

Amartya Sen is a renowned Indian economist, philosopher, and Nobel laureate. Born on November 3, 1933, in Bengal, India, Sen grew up in a family of intellectuals and was educated at Presidency College, Calcutta University, and Trinity College, Cambridge. He began his academic career at the London School of Economics and later taught at the University of Oxford and Harvard University. Sen's work focuses on welfare economics, development economics, and the applications of economic theory to social issues, particularly in the areas of poverty, inequality, and human rights. He is known for his critique of traditional utilitarianism and his emphasis on the importance of individual freedoms and capabilities. Sen has received numerous awards for his contributions to economics and social justice, including the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences in 1998.

Isadore Sharp is a renowned Canadian businessman and philanthropist, best known as the founder, chairman, and CEO of the Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts. Sharp was born on July 15, 1923, in Toronto, Canada, and grew up in a working-class family. Despite facing financial challenges during his early years, Sharp pursued his passion for hospitality and opened his first hotel, the All Seasons Motor Hotel, in Toronto in 1961. Over the years, he expanded the business and established the Four Seasons brand, which has become synonymous with luxury and excellence in the hospitality industry. Sharp is also known for his commitment to philanthropy, particularly in the fields of healthcare, education, and the arts.

Elizabeth Blackwell (1821-1910) was the first woman in the United States to earn a medical degree. Born in England, she immigrated to the United States with her family at the age of 13. Despite facing gender discrimination and opposition from many in the medical community, Blackwell persisted in pursuing her dream of becoming a physician. She earned her medical degree from Geneva Medical College in 1849, and went on to establish a successful medical practice in New York City. Blackwell was also a pioneer in the field of public health, advocating for improved sanitation and hygiene practices in urban areas. Throughout her life, Blackwell faced numerous challenges due to her gender, but her determination and dedication to her work paved the way for future generations of women in medicine.

Nobu Matsuhisa is a renowned Japanese chef and restaurateur, born in Sichuan Province, China, in 1959. He grew up in Tokyo, Japan, where he began his culinary career as a sushi chef. In 1987, he moved to Los Angeles and opened his first restaurant, Matsuhisa, which quickly gained recognition for its innovative blend of traditional Japanese cuisine with Southern California flavors. Since then, he has expanded his empire to include several successful restaurants around the world, including Nobu Malibu, Nobu London, and Nobu Ibiza. Matsuhisa is known for his signature dishes, such as black cod with miso and sesame, and his use of fresh, organic ingredients. He has also collaborated with other celebrities, including Robert De Niro and Meir Yohai, to open additional restaurants.

Larry Page is an American computer scientist and entrepreneur who co-founded Google Inc., the world's most popular search engine. Born on March 19, 1973, in Lansing, Michigan, Page grew up in East Lansing, where he showed early interest in computers and programming. He graduated from the University of Michigan with a degree in computer science in 1995. Page dropped out of his PhD program at Stanford University in 1995 to co-found Google with Sergey Brin. As the CEO of Alphabet Inc., the parent company of Google, Page has led the company to become the most valuable company in the world, with a net worth of over $60 billion. He is known for his innovative approach to business and technology, and has received numerous awards for his contributions to the field.

Winona LaDuke is a Native American environmentalist and political activist. She was born on July 7, 1953, in Portland, Oregon. LaDuke is of Anishinaabe ancestry and is a member of the White Earth Nation. She graduated from Harvard University with a degree in economics and later earned a master's degree in urban planning from Antioch University. LaDuke has worked extensively on issues related to indigenous rights, environmental justice, and sustainable development. She was a Green Party candidate for vice president in 1996 and has written several books on environmental and social justice issues.

Greta Gerwig is an American actress and filmmaker, born on February 26, 1983, in Sacramento, California. She began her acting career in the early 2000s, appearing in small roles in films and television shows. Gerwig's breakout role came in 2012 when she starred in the indie comedy "Frances Ha." She gained critical acclaim for her performance and went on to appear in several other notable films, including "Mistress America" and "Lady Bird," both of which she also wrote. In 2018, Gerwig made her directorial debut with "Lady Bird," which earned her numerous awards and nominations, including an Academy Award nomination for Best Director.

José Mujica was born in Montevideo, Uruguay in 1935. Mujica studied law at the National University of Uruguay and later became involved in the Tupac Amaru guerrilla movement, which fought against the military dictatorship that ruled Uruguay from 1973 to 1985. After being arrested and tortured by the military, Mujica spent 13 years in prison before being released in 1985. He later became a member of the Broad Front coalition and was elected president of Uruguay in 2010, serving until 2015. During his presidency, Mujica focused on reducing poverty and inequality, legalizing marijuana, and promoting environmental policies. He is known for his simple lifestyle and is often referred to as the "poorest president in the world."

Hideki Matsuyama is a Japanese professional golfer who was born on February 29, 1992, in prefecture of Mie, Japan. He turned professional in 2009 and began competing on the Japan Golf Tour, where he won several tournaments before making his PGA Tour debut in 2013. Matsuyama quickly established himself as one of the top players on the tour, winning the 2014 Memorial Tournament and finishing as runner-up at the 2015 Masters Tournament. He has also represented Japan in international competitions such as the World Golf Championships and the Olympics. He is known for his powerful driving and accurate iron play, and has been nicknamed "The Golden Child" of Japanese golf.

Alex Morgan was born in San Dimas, California on July 2, 1989. She is an American soccer player who plays as a forward for Orlando Pride in the National Women's Soccer League (NWSL) and the United States women's national soccer team. Morgan began playing soccer at a young age and quickly emerged as a rising star in the sport. In 2012, she helped lead the USA to the gold medal at the London Olympics, scoring the game-winning goal in the final. Morgan has also won two NWSL championships and was named the NWSL Most Valuable Player in 2013. She is known for her speed, agility, and goal-scoring ability, and is widely regarded as one of the best female soccer players in the world.

Born into slavery in 1797 in New York, Sojourner Truth escaped to freedom in 1826 and became one of the most powerful abolitionist speakers during the Civil War era. She traveled across the country, giving speeches against slavery and women's rights, advocating for racial equality and gender equality. Her famous 'Ain't I a Woman?' speech delivered at the Ohio Women's Rights Convention in 1851 is considered a cornerstone of feminist literature. Truth died in 1883, but her legacy lives on as a symbol of hope and courage for generations to come.

Elon Musk is a successful entrepreneur and business magnate known for his innovative ideas and ambitious goals in the fields of technology and energy. He was born in Pretoria, South Africa in 1971 and moved to Canada in 1992 to attend college. Musk co-founded PayPal in 1998 and sold it to eBay for $1.5 billion in 2002. He then went on to found SpaceX in 2002, Tesla in 2003, Neuralink in 2016, and The Boring Company in 2016. Musk is known for his vision of a sustainable future powered by renewable energy and his efforts to reduce global warming through the development of electric cars and space exploration.

Cindy Sherman is a renowned American photographer and artist known for her conceptual and often provocative images that explore identity, gender, and representation. Sherman was born on February 19, 1954, in Glen Ridge, New Jersey, and grew up in a suburban area. She earned a BFA in photography from the State University of New York at Buffalo in 1976, and then moved to New York City to pursue her artistic career. Sherman's groundbreaking body of work often features herself as the model, employing various costumes, makeup, and prosthetics to create complex and layered narratives. Through her art, Sherman challenges the notion of a fixed identity and questions the ways in which women are represented in society. Her work has been exhibited extensively around the world and is held in high regard within the art world.

Katie Couric is a renowned American television journalist, born on November 7, 1957, in Arlington, Virginia. After graduating from the University of Virginia, Couric began her career at WTVJ-TV in Miami, before joining NBC News in 1989. She became the first woman to anchor the evening news when she took over as anchor of 'NBC Nightly News' in 2006. Couric has won numerous awards for her reporting, including two Emmy Awards and a Peabody Award. In 2011, she left NBC News to host 'CBS Evening News,' becoming the first female solo anchor of a major evening newscast.

Bad Bunny is a Puerto Rican rapper, singer, and songwriter. His real name is Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio. Born on March 10, 1994, in San Juan, Puerto Rico, Bad Bunny gained popularity with his debut single "Diles" in 2016. His breakthrough came with the album "X 100pre" in 2018, which included hits like "I Like It" featuring J Balvin and Cardi B. Since then, he has become one of the most successful Latin trap artists in the world. He has collaborated with several big-name artists and has won several awards, including a Grammy Award for Best Latin Rock, Urban or Alternative Album.

Esther Duflo is a French-American economist and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Born in Paris, France, in 1972, she grew up in a family of intellectuals and received her undergraduate degree from the University of Paris-Dauphine. Duflo earned her Ph.D. in economics from the London School of Economics and then moved to the United States to pursue her research and teaching career. Her work focuses on developing countries, poverty, and policy interventions, and she is known for her innovative field experiments that test the effectiveness of different policies. In 2015, she was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences jointly with Abhijit Banerjee for their experimental approach to alleviating global poverty.

Richard Pryor was an American comedian and actor known for his unflinching and biting humor. Born in Peoria, Illinois on December 10, 1940, Pryor grew up in a brothel in Sacramento, California where his mother worked as a prostitute. After serving in the Marines and getting involved in petty crimes, Pryor turned to stand-up comedy in the late 1960s. He quickly rose to fame with his raw, honest, and often controversial comedy style, addressing topics such as race relations, sex, and drug abuse. Pryor appeared in several films, including 'The Richard Pryor Show,' 'Car Wash,' and 'Superman III.' Despite struggling with multiple sclerosis, Pryor continued to perform until his death in 2005. His legacy as a groundbreaking comedian and social critic continues to inspire new generations of comedians.

Born on August 26, 1908, in Kansas City, Missouri, Tex Avery was an American cartoonist, animator, and director. Avery began his career at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) studios, where he worked as an animator on films such as 'The Gold Diggers of 1933.' In 1935, he left MGM to join Warner Bros., where he created some of his most famous works, including 'Red Hot Riding Hood' (1936), 'Tweetie Pie' (1947), and 'Rudolf the Red-Nosed Reindeer' (1949). Known for his energetic and humorous style, Avery is considered one of the most influential animators in the history of animation.

David Khari Webber Chappelle was born on August 31, 1973, in Washington, D.C. to a single mother. Raised by his grandparents, Chappelle discovered stand-up comedy at the age of 14 and began performing at local clubs. After graduating high school, he moved to New York City to pursue a career in comedy. Chappelle's big break came in 1998 when he landed his own show on ABC, 'Chappelle's Show,' which became a hit and launched him into superstardom. Since then, he has starred in several films and television shows, including 'The Dave Chappelle Show' on Comedy Central and 'Key & Peele.' He has also won numerous awards for his work, including multiple Emmy Awards and Grammy Awards.

Zaha Hadid was a renowned architect, designer, and artist born in Baghdad, Iraq in 1950. She studied mathematics at the American University of Beirut before moving to London to study architecture at the Architectural Association School of Architecture. Hadid established her own practice, Zaha Hadid Architects, in 1980, and quickly gained international recognition for her futuristic and innovative designs. She became the first woman to receive the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 2004. Known for her curvaceous and dynamic structures, Hadid designed buildings across the world, including the Heydar Aliyev Center in Baku, Azerbaijan, and the Guangzhou Opera House in China. Hadid passed away in 2016, leaving behind a legacy of pioneering architecture.

Mary Wollstonecraft (1759-1797) was an English writer, philosopher, and advocate for women's rights. She was born in London, England, and educated at home before attending a boarding school. In 1788, she published her most famous work, "A Vindication of the Rights of Woman," which argued that women should be treated as rational beings and not just as sexual objects or domestic servants. Wollstonecraft challenged traditional gender roles and stereotypes, advocating for women's education and intellectual equality. Her other notable works include "Thoughts on the Education of Daughters" and "The Wrongs of Woman." She died shortly after giving birth to her daughter, Fanny Blood.

Warren Buffett is an American businessman, investor, and philanthropist, widely considered as one of the most successful investors in history. Buffett is the CEO of Berkshire Hathaway and has led the company to become one of the largest and most successful companies in the world. Born in Omaha, Nebraska, in 1930, Buffett began his investment career in high school, buying his first stock at the age of 11. He studied business at the University of Pennsylvania and worked as a stockbroker before starting his own investment partnership in 1956. Over the years, Buffett has been known for his value investing philosophy, which involves buying undervalued companies and holding them for long periods. He is also known for his generosity, having pledged to give away the majority of his wealth during his lifetime and beyond.

George Carlin (December 12, 1937 - June 22, 2008) was an American stand-up comedian, actor, author, and social critic. He is widely regarded as one of the most important and influential comedians of the 20th century. Carlin was known for his irreverent style, which often opened up into observations about society, politics, religion, and philosophy. Throughout his career, he won numerous awards, including four Grammy Awards, and was posthumously awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. He is remembered for his bold and unapologetic humor that tackled controversial topics head-on.

Quentin Tarantino is a renowned American film director, writer, producer, and actor. He was born on March 27, 1963, in Knoxville, Tennessee, and grew up in California. Tarantino began his career as a video store clerk before making his way into the film industry as an assistant editor. His breakthrough came with the release of his debut feature film 'Reservoir Dogs' in 1992, which received critical acclaim and established him as a rising star in the filmmaking world. Since then, Tarantino has directed numerous successful films such as 'Pulp Fiction,' 'Jackie Brown,' 'Kill Bill,' and 'Django Unchained,' all of which have garnered him widespread recognition and numerous awards. He is known for his unique directing style, non-linear storytelling, and memorable characters.

Simone Biles is a professional gymnast who was born on March 14, 1997, in Columbus, Ohio. She began her gymnastics career at the age of 6 and quickly rose to fame after winning numerous national and international titles, including four gold medals at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. Biles is known for her incredible strength, flexibility, and precision on the balance beam, floor exercise, and vault. She has won a total of 25 World Championship medals, 19 Olympic medals, and has been named the Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year three times.

Novak Djokovic is a Serbian professional tennis player and one of the greatest tennis players of all time. Born on May 22, 1987, in Belgrade, Yugoslavia (now Serbia), Djokovic began playing tennis at a young age and quickly rose through the junior ranks. He turned professional in 2003 and has since become one of the most dominant players in the sport, winning 18 Grand Slam titles, including 13 in singles, 3 in doubles, and 2 in mixed doubles. He has also won numerous ATP World Tour titles and holds the record for the most weeks spent at number one in the ATP Rankings. Djokovic is known for his athleticism, endurance, and mental toughness on the court, as well as his charitable work off the court.

Ayn Rand (born Alisa Zinov'yevna Rosenbaum) was a Russian-American writer, philosopher, playwright, and novelist. She was born on February 2, 1905, in Saint Petersburg, Russia, and immigrated to the United States in 1916. Rand's philosophical works, particularly 'The Fountainhead' and 'Atlas Shrugged,' have had a significant influence on modern conservative thought. Her ideas about individualism, capitalism, and limited government have made her a controversial figure in political and intellectual circles.

Rumi (1207-1273) was a Persian poet, scholar, and Sufi mystic. Born in what is now Afghanistan, Rumi grew up in a cultural and intellectual environment that influenced his writing. His works, which include poems and letters, are considered some of the most important in Islamic literature. Rumi's poetry is known for its beauty and spiritual depth, exploring themes of love, faith, and the human condition. He is considered one of the greatest poets of all time and his legacy has continued to inspire generations of readers and scholars.

Constantin Brâncuși (1876-1957) was a Romanian sculptor, painter, and photographer who is often considered one of the most important artists of the 20th century. Brâncuși was born in Hobita, Romania and began his artistic career as a carver and goldsmith. He moved to Paris in 1904 and quickly gained recognition for his innovative sculptures, which were characterized by their simplicity, elegance, and use of abstract forms. Brâncuși's work was influenced by his native Romania and the traditional folk art of the region. Throughout his career, he created over 300 sculptures, many of which are now held in museums around the world. Brâncuși also worked in painting and photography, and his work continues to inspire artists and art lovers to this day.

James Watt (born March 10, 1932) is an American engineer, entrepreneur, and conservative political activist. He is known for his contributions to the development of the modern steam turbine and gas turbine technology. Watt earned his Bachelor of Science degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Michigan in 1954 and his Master of Science degree in aero/astro engineering from Caltech in 1956. He worked at General Electric for 35 years, where he developed the Watt steam turbine, which revolutionized the electric power industry. Watt has received numerous awards for his work, including the National Medal of Technology in 1986. He is also a vocal critic of environmental regulations and has been involved in various political campaigns.

Christiaan Barnard was a South African cardiothoracic surgeon who performed the first successful heart transplant in 1967. Barnard was born on November 8, 1922, in Cape Town, South Africa. He qualified as a doctor at the University of Cape Town in 1948 and later trained in thoracic surgery at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. In 1967, he performed the first human-to-human heart transplant, which was a groundbreaking operation that changed the field of medicine forever. Barnard continued to innovate in the field of cardiac surgery throughout his career and was awarded numerous accolades for his work, including the Order of the Companions of OR Tambo in 1999. He died in 2001 at the age of 78.

Jorge Mario Bergoglio was born on December 17, 1936, in Buenos Aires, Argentina. He studied literature and philosophy at the Jesuit Colegio de San Jose, and later earned a degree in philosophy from the Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina. He joined the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) in 1958, and was ordained as a priest in 1969. Bergoglio served as the archbishop of Buenos Aires from 1998 to 2013, before being elected as the Pope in 2013, taking the name Francis. He is known for his progressive stance on social issues, and his efforts to reform the Roman Curia and promote ecumenism.

Tina Fey is a multi-talented American actress, comedian, writer, and producer. She was born on May 18, 1970, in Upper Darby, Pennsylvania. Fey studied playwriting at the University of Virginia and began her career as a comedy performer in Chicago. She rose to fame in 1997 when she became a cast member on Saturday Night Live (SNL), where she created several memorable characters, including Sarah Palin. Fey has also written several books, including her memoir, 'Bossypants,' and has starred in films such as 'Mean Girls' and '30 Rock.'

Samuel Morse (April 27, 1791 - April 2, 1872) was an American artist and inventor. He was best known for his work on the telegraph, which revolutionized long-distance communication. Morse was born in New Haven, Connecticut, and studied art at Yale University. He later moved to Europe, where he became a successful portrait painter. In the 1830s, Morse turned his attention to inventing, and developed the telegraph system that became widely used throughout the United States and Europe. The Morse Code, a system of dots and dashes used to transmit messages over the telegraph, is named after him.
train_generations: Edward R. Murrow (1908-1965) was an American broadcast journalist and news anchor, known for his distinctive voice, in-depth reporting, and strong convictions. Murrow was born in Pocatello, Idaho, and began his journalism career in radio during the 1930s, working for various stations before joining CBS Radio in 1940. Throughout his career, Murrow covered many major events, including World War II, the Cold War, and the Korean War. He was particularly known for his coverage of McCarthyism and the Red Scare, and his critiques of political corruption and propaganda. Murrow's legacy continues to influence modern journalism, and he is widely regarded as one of the greatest reporters in American history.

Stephanie Kwolek was a Polish-American chemist and engineer born on November 27, 1923, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. She graduated from Cornell University in 1946 with a degree in chemistry and later earned her Ph.D. in polymer chemistry from Columbia University in 1952. Kwoleks career at DuPont spanned over 40 years, during which she developed the first high-performance polyurethane polymers, including the popular Kevlar fiber. Her work led to numerous patents and awards, including the National Medal of Technology in 1994. Kwolek died on June 18, 2006, at the age of 82.

Harvey Milk (1930-1978) was an American politician and LGBTQ+ rights activist. Born in Long Island, New York, Milk moved to San Francisco in 1972 to live openly as a gay man. He was one of the first openly gay elected officials in the United States, serving on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors from 1978 until his assassination in 1978. Milk's legacy has continued to inspire LGBTQ+ rights movements worldwide, and he has been recognized as a martyr and icon for the community.

Priyanka Chopra is a Bollywood actress, singer, film producer, philanthropist, and the winner of Miss World 2000. She was born on July 18, 1982, in Jamshedpur, India, to Dr. Ashok and Dr. Madhu Chopra. After completing her education, Priyanka began her acting career in Bollywood films in 2003 and has since appeared in over 50 films, including 'Fashion,' 'Dostana,' 'Barfi!,' and 'Quantico.' In addition to acting, Priyanka has also won several awards for her work in Indian cinema, including ten Filmfare Awards. She has also made her mark in Hollywood with roles in 'Baywatch' and 'Joker.'

Darius Khondji is a renowned Iranian-born French cinematographer, known for his work in film and television. Born on July 19, 1955, in Tehran, Iran, Khondji moved to Paris at the age of 15 to pursue his passion for photography and cinema. After studying at the prestigious Louis Lumière Film School, he began his career as a camera operator and lighting technician in the early 1980s. Over the course of his illustrious career, Khondji has collaborated with some of the most acclaimed directors in the industry, including Wes Anderson, Christopher Nolan, and David Fincher. Some of his notable works include "Seven," "Midnight Sky," and "The Great Gatsby." Khondji has received numerous awards and nominations for his exceptional contributions to the world of cinematography, including an Academy Award nomination for Best Cinematography.

Evo Morales is a Bolivian politician who served as the President of Bolivia from 2006 to 2019. Born on October 21, 1959, in the rural town of Belén, near the Chilean border, Morales grew up in poverty and became involved in coca farming at a young age. He founded the socialist movement Movement for Socialism (MAS) in 1998, which won the presidency in 2005. During his tenure, Morales implemented policies aimed at reducing poverty and inequality, including nationalizing natural resources and redistributing land to small farmers. He also pursued closer ties with Cuba and Venezuela, and sought to address climate change through alternative energy sources. Morales was the first indigenous president in Bolivian history and remains a prominent figure in Latin American politics.

George Washington (1732-1799) was the commander-in-chief of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War and is often referred to as the "Father of Our Country." He was born in Westmoreland County, Virginia, to a family of English and Scottish descent. Washington's military and political career began in the 1750s, when he served as a major in the Virginia militia during the French and Indian War. He later became a delegate to the Continental Congress, where he played a leading role in the fight for independence from Britain. In 1789, he was unanimously elected as the first President of the United States, serving two terms until 1797. He set many precedents for the executive branch, including the cabinet system and the inaugural address. He retired to Mount Vernon, his plantation in Virginia, after his presidency, and died in 1799. He is remembered for his integrity, honesty, and leadership, and is often depicted on currency

Frida Kahlo (July 6, 1907 - July 13, 1954) was a Mexican artist known for her self-portraits and depiction of Mexican culture. She was born in Coyoacan, Mexico City, and grew up in a family of artists. Frida suffered a devastating bus accident at the age of 18, which left her with multiple injuries, including a broken spine, pelvis, and leg. The accident had a profound effect on her life and art. Despite her physical suffering, Kahlo continued to paint, producing over 200 paintings throughout her lifetime. Her work often explores themes of identity, gender, class, and race, as well as her own experiences with pain and suffering. Today, Frida Kahlo is recognized as one of the most important artists of the 20th century, and her work continues to inspire and influence artists around the world.

Slavoj Žižek is a contemporary philosopher and cultural critic, born in Ljubljana, Slovenia, in 1949. He studied philosophy at the University of Ljubljana and later at the University of Paris. Žižek is known for his controversial and provocative theories, which challenge traditional notions of ideology, capitalism, and the human condition. He has written numerous books, including "The Sublime Object of Ideology" and "In Defense of Lost Causes." Žižek is also a prominent public intellectual, frequently contributing to newspapers and magazines, and delivering lectures and interviews worldwide. He is a professor at the University of London and lives in Paris.

Alvin Ailey (January 5, 1955 - December 1, 1989) was an African American dancer, choreographer, and founder of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, based in New York City. Ailey was born in Rogers, Texas, and began his dance training at the age of 7 at the Los Angeles County High School for the Arts. He studied dance at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), and later at the Juilliard School in New York City. Ailey's choreography was characterized by its fusion of modern, jazz, and African dance techniques, and often explored themes of race, identity, and social justice. His most famous work, "Revelations," is still performed by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater today, more than 50 years after its premiere. Ailey was also known for his advocacy for racial equality and social justice, and he worked tirelessly to promote diversity and inclusion in the world of dance.

Yuna Kim is a South Korean figure skater who was born on July 6, 1990, in Jeonju, North Jeolla Province, South Korea. She began skating at the age of five and quickly rose through the ranks, winning numerous junior competitions before making her senior debut in 2006. In 2010, Yuna won the gold medal at the Vancouver Olympics, becoming the first Korean female figure skater to win an Olympic gold medal. She also won two silver medals at the World Figure Skating Championships (2009 and 2011) and a bronze medal at the 2014 Sochi Olympics. Yuna is known for her technical precision, artistic expression, and consistently high scores, earning her the nickname "Queen of Figures."

Jackie Chan is a Hong Kong-based martial artist, actor, stuntman, and film director. Born Chan Kong-sang on April 7, 1954, in Hong Kong, he trained in the Peking Opera at a young age, before becoming a stuntman in the film industry. With over 150 films to his credit, including 'Rush Hour,' 'Shanghai Noon,' and 'Kung Fu Hustle,' Chan has become one of the most recognizable actors worldwide, known for performing his own stunts and blending comedy and martial arts in his films.

Born in Warsaw, Poland in 1867, Marie Curie grew up in a family that valued education. She pursued her higher studies in France, earning a doctorate in physics. She met her future husband, Pierre Curie, at the Sorbonne and together they conducted pioneering research in radioactivity, leading to their discovery of two new elements, polonium and radium. Marie Curie became the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, in 1903, and the first person to win two Nobel Prizes in different fields (physics and chemistry) in 1911. She died in 1934 after a long illness caused by her exposure to radiation.

Karl Marx was born in Trier, Prussia (now Germany) on May 5, 1818. His father was a Jewish lawyer, and his mother was a Belgian. Marx studied law at the University of Berlin but became more interested in philosophy and economics. In 1843, Marx moved to Paris where he began writing his most famous work, 'Das Kapital.' In 1849, he married Jenny von Westphalen, and they had seven children together. Marx's ideas about communism and the labor movement led to his exile from several countries. He died in London on March 14, 1883.

Rachel Anne Maddow was born in 1973 in Castro Valley, California. She earned her degree in public policy from Stanford University in 1994. After working as a radio host, Maddow joined MSNBC in 2008 as a political analyst and host of 'The Rachel Maddow Show.' Her show focuses on political news and analysis, and has gained a large following since its inception. Maddow is openly gay and has been a prominent advocate for LGBTQ+ rights.

Jamie Oliver is a British chef, restaurateur, and food activist. Born on May 27, 1975, in Clavering, Essex, England, Oliver grew up in a family of cooks and began his culinary career at a young age. After training at the Catering College in Southend, he worked in several restaurants before landing his own cooking show on the BBC, "The Naked Chef," in 1999. Since then, Oliver has become a household name, hosting several successful television shows and opening multiple restaurants around the world. He is known for his passion for using fresh, locally-sourced ingredients and promoting healthy eating habits.

John Maynard Keynes (1883-1946) was a British economist, whose ideas about government intervention in economic affairs revolutionized economic thought. He studied at Cambridge University, where he earned his bachelor's degree in 1904 and his master's degree in 1905. Keynes' most famous work is "The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money," published in 1936, which challenged the traditional laissez-faire approach to economic policy. His ideas have had a profound impact on modern economics and continue to shape economic policy around the world.

Edward Alexander Bouchet (September 15, 1852 - October 28, 1918) was an American physicist and chemist. Bouchet was born in New Haven, Connecticut and grew up in a family of former slaves. He graduated from Yale College in 1874, and later earned his PhD from Yale in 1879. Bouchet was a professor of physics at Howard University and also served as the dean of the college of arts and sciences. He made significant contributions to the field of physics and was one of the first African Americans to earn a doctorate in science.

Hammurabi (c. 1754 BC - c. 1728 BC) was an Amorite king of Babylon from 1792 BC to 1750 BC. He is best known for being the sixth king of the First Dynasty of Babylon and the most famous ruler of the Old Babylonian period. Hammurabi ruled Babylon during a time of great prosperity and cultural development, which saw significant advancements in law, architecture, and trade. Under his rule, Babylon became a powerful empire that stretched from the Mediterranean Sea to the Persian Gulf. He is also famous for being the lawgiver of Babylon, who codified the laws of Babylon in the Code of Hammurabi, which is one of the oldest surviving legal codes.

Albert Einstein (1879-1955) was a German-born physicist, philosopher, and mathematician who is widely regarded as one of the greatest minds in modern history. He is best known for his theory of relativity and the famous equation E=mc². Einstein was born in Munich, Germany, and grew up in a middle-class Jewish family. He studied physics at the Swiss Federal Polytechnic and later became a lecturer at the University of Berlin. In 1933, after Hitler came to power in Germany, Einstein moved to the United States, where he became a citizen in 1940. Throughout his life, Einstein was recognized for his contributions to science, including the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921. He also advocated for peace, civil rights, and social justice, and his legacy continues to inspire people around the world.

Ludwig van Beethoven (1770-1827) was a German composer and pianist, widely regarded as one of the most significant figures in the history of classical music. Born in Bonn, Germany, Beethoven displayed his musical talents at an early age and was largely self-taught. He moved to Vienna in 1792 and gained recognition as a virtuoso pianist and composer, earning the title "Rockstar of his time." Beethoven's compositions include symphonies, piano sonatas, string quartets, and operas, and are known for their technical innovation and expressive depth. He is particularly famous for his Symphony No. 5 and Symphony No. 9, considered some of the greatest works of classical music ever composed.

Born on February 18, 1931, in Lorain, Ohio, Toni Morrison is a renowned American novelist, editor, and professor emerita at Princeton University. She is known for her powerful and poignant works that delve into the experiences of African Americans. Morrison's novels often explore themes of race, identity, history, and the African American struggle for freedom and equality. Her most notable works include 'The Bluest Eye', 'Sula', 'Song of Solomon', 'Beloved', and 'A Mercy'. Morrison has received numerous awards for her literary contributions, including the Pulitzer Prize, Nobel Prize in Literature, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

Michael Phelps is a world-renowned swimmer and the most decorated Olympian of all time, with 28 medals, including 23 gold medals. He was born on June 30, 1985, in Baltimore, Maryland, and began swimming at the age of seven. Phelps won his first Olympic gold medal at the age of 15 in Sydney in 2000, and went on to win more than 100 national titles throughout his career. He is known for his incredible speed and endurance in the water, and has broken numerous world records throughout his career.

Octavia Butler (June 22, 1947 - February 24, 2006) was an American science fiction writer. She was the first black woman to win the Hugo Award and the Nebula Award. Her works explore issues of race, power, gender, and identity. Some of her notable works include "Kindred," "Parable of the Sower," and "Fledgling." Throughout her career, Butler received numerous awards and accolades for her contributions to literature. She is widely regarded as one of the most important and influential science fiction writers of her generation.

Christiane Amanpour is a renowned British-American journalist, anchor, and correspondent for CNN International. Born in London in 1958, Amanpour studied law at the University of oxford before pursuing a career in journalism. She began her career in television at BBC Newsnight and later moved to CNN in 1983, where she became a prominent international correspondent, reporting on major global events including the Gulf War, the Bosnian War, and the Arab Spring. Amanpour has received numerous awards for her work, including a Emmy, Peabody, and a MacArthur Fellowship.

Diego Armando Maradona was born in Lanus, Buenos Aires, Argentina, on October 30, 1960. He is considered one of the greatest soccer players of all time, known for his exceptional dribbling skills, vision, and goalscoring ability. Maradona began his professional career at the age of 16 with Argentinos Juniors, before moving to Barcelona in 1982. He played for Napoli in Italy, where he led the team to two league titles and a UEFA Cup victory. Maradona also represented Argentina in three World Cups, leading the team to victory in 1986, and earning himself the FIFA World Cup Golden Ball award. He is often referred to as "The God of Football."

Judy Garland was an American actress and singer who rose to fame during the 1930s and 1940s. Born Frances Ethel Gumm on June 10, 1922, in Grand Rapids, Minnesota, she was raised by her vaudeville performer parents. Garland began performing at a young age and gained widespread recognition after starring in the 1939 film "The Wizard of Oz." Throughout her career, Garland appeared in numerous films, including "A Star is Born," "Meet Me in St. Louis," and "Easter Parade." Known for her powerful voice and emotional performances, Garland struggled with personal demons, including drug addiction, and died in 1969 at the age of 47.

Thomas Edward Patrick Brady Jr., better known as Tom Brady, is an American football quarterback who plays for the New England Patriots in the National Football League (NFL). He was born on August 3, 1977, in San Mateo, California, and grew up in a Catholic family with two older sisters and a younger brother. Brady played college football at the University of Michigan, where he won a national championship in 1997. He was drafted by the Patriots in the sixth round of the 2000 NFL Draft and has been playing for the team ever since, leading them to six Super Bowl wins and four Super Bowl MVP awards. Brady is widely considered one of the greatest quarterbacks in NFL history, known for his accuracy, pocket presence, and leadership. He is also known for his high level of fitness and dedication to training, which has contributed to his longevity in the league.

Kimberly Noel Kardashian was born in Los Angeles, California, to Robert and Kris Jenner. She rose to fame after the release of a sex tape featuring her and her ex-boyfriend, rapper Ray J. The tape led to the creation of the E! reality show 'Keeping Up with the Kardashians,' which follows the lives of Kim and her family. Kim Kardashian has since become a successful businesswoman, launching several clothing lines, beauty products, and mobile apps. She has also been involved in various philanthropic efforts, particularly in the area of prison reform.

Hakeem Olajuwon, also known as The Dream, is a retired Nigerian-American professional basketball player. Born on January 21, 1963, in Lagos, Nigeria, he moved to the United States at the age of 13 and grew up in Houston, Texas. Olajuwon played college basketball at the University of Houston, leading the Cougars to two NCAA Tournament appearances before being drafted by the Houston Rockets in 1984. He played 17 seasons in the NBA, all with the Rockets, and led the team to back-to-back NBA championships in 1994 and 1995. Olajuwon was named the NBA Finals MVP both years and was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2008.

Agatha Christie (1890-1976) was an English writer best known for her mystery novels. Born in Torquay, Devon, England, Christie grew up in a wealthy family and was educated at home. After her marriage to Archibald Christie in 1914, she wrote her first novel, 'The Mysterious Affair at Styles,' which introduced the character of Hercule Poirot. Over the course of her long career, Christie wrote more than 60 novels and numerous short stories, including 'Murder on the Orient Express' and 'Death on the Nile.' Christie's works have been translated into more than 100 languages and have sold millions of copies worldwide. She is widely regarded as the queen of crime fiction.

Elvis Aaron Presley was born in Tupelo, Mississippi, on January 8, 1935, to Gladys and Vernon Presley. His family moved to Memphis, Tennessee when he was a child, where he grew up and developed his love for music. Elvis is known as the "King of Rock and Roll" and is widely regarded as one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century. He began his music career in the mid-1950s with Sun Records and rose to fame in the early 1960s with RCA Victor. Known for his charismatic stage presence and unique voice, Elvis' music blended rockabilly, gospel, blues, and country, creating a distinct sound that influenced generations of musicians. Elvis died in 1977 at the age of 42 due to a heart attack.

Michael Joseph Jackson (August 29, 1958 - June 25, 2009) was an American singer, songwriter, musician, and dancer. Dubbed the "King of Pop," he was born in Gary, Indiana, and rose to fame at age 11 as a member of the Jackson 5. He went solo in 1971 and became one of the most popular artists of all time, known for his iconic albums such as "Off the Wall" (1979), "Thriller" (1982), and "Bad" (1987). His music videos, including "Billie Jean" and "Thriller," are considered some of the greatest of all time. Jackson won numerous awards, including 13 Grammy Awards, and was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame twice. He passed away in 2009 due to an overdose of propofol and benzodiazepine.

Paul Farmer is a global health activist and medical anthropologist born in 1957 in Boston, Massachusetts. He is the co-founder of Partners in Health (PIH), an organization that provides medical care and advocacy to disadvantaged communities worldwide. Farmer received his A.B. degree in Anthropology from Harvard University and his M.D. degree from the University of California, San Francisco. He has written extensively on the subject of global health and social justice, including the books 'Infections and Inequalities' and 'Pathologies of Power.' Farmer has been recognized with numerous awards, including the MacArthur Fellowship, for his contributions to improving healthcare in resource-poor settings.

Milton Glaser is a renowned American graphic designer and illustrator, born in New York City in 1929. He is known for his innovative and iconic designs that have become part of popular culture. Throughout his career, Glaser has worked on a wide range of projects, including magazine design, branding, and advertising. He is also the co-founder of New York Magazine and the School of Visual Arts. His work has been recognized with numerous awards, including the AIGA Gold Medal, and he continues to be an influential figure in the design world.

Amelia Mary Earhart was born on July 24, 1897, in Atchison, Kansas, USA. She was an aviation pioneer and author, known for being the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Amelia's interest in flying began at a young age, and she received her pilot's license in 1923. Throughout her career, she broke numerous records for speed and altitude, and became a symbol of women's empowerment in aviation. Earhart disappeared during a flight around the world in 1937, and her disappearance remains one of the greatest mysteries in aviation history.

Charles Lindbergh was a famous American aviator, inventor, explorer, and activist. Born on February 4, 1902, in Detroit, Michigan, Lindbergh grew up in a modest home and showed an early interest in mechanics and engineering. After serving in the Army Air Service during World War I, Lindbergh earned his pilot's license in 1922. On May 20-21, 1927, he made history by flying solo nonstop across the Atlantic Ocean, from New York to Paris, in his single-engine monoplane, The Spirit of St. Louis. This historic flight made Lindbergh an overnight sensation and catapulted him into the national spotlight. Throughout his life, Lindbergh remained committed to his principles and was known for his independence, determination, and courage. He continued to fly, advocate, and write until his tragic death on August 26, 1974.

Jet Li is a Chinese martial artist, actor, film producer, and wushu champion. He was born on April 26, 1963, in Peking (now Beijing), China. Li began training in traditional Kung Fu at the age of 11 and won numerous awards in local and national competitions. After entering the film industry, Li became one of the most recognizable figures in Hong Kong cinema, known for his roles in films such as 'Romeo Must Die,' 'Kiss of the Dragon,' and 'Olympus Has Fallen.' He has also been recognized as a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador since 2008.

Yo is a famous yo-yo player from Japan. He was born on May 27, 1996, in Tokyo, Japan. Yo started playing yo-yo at the age of 11 and quickly became one of the best in the world. He won the World Yo-Yo Championship in 2015 and has been featured in numerous yo-yo competitions and videos. Yo is known for his unique and innovative tricks, as well as his friendly and humble personality. He continues to inspire and influence the yo-yo community through his performances and teachings.

Cleopatra (69 BC - 30 BC) was the last pharaoh of Ancient Egypt, known for her political and romantic alliances with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony. She was born in Alexandria, Egypt, and ascended to the throne after the death of her father, Ptolemy XII. Throughout her reign, Cleopatra sought to protect Egypt from the expanding Roman Empire, forming alliances and using her charms to influence powerful Roman leaders. Her life and legacy have been the subject of much historical debate and fascination, with many depictions in art and literature.

Mary Baker Eddy (1821-1910) was a prominent American religious leader, writer, and philanthropist. Born in Bow, New Hampshire, she founded the Church of Christ, Scientist in 1879. Her book, "Science and Health with Key to the Scriptures," is considered the primary text of the Christian Science movement. Through her writings and teachings, Eddy aimed to promote spiritual healing, social reform, and humanitarian work. Her legacy continues to inspire millions of followers worldwide.

Rafael Nadal Parera is a Spanish professional tennis player, born on June 3, 1986, in Manacor, Mallorca, Spain. Nadal's tennis career began at a young age, and he quickly rose through the junior ranks to become one of the top players in the world. He turned professional in 2001 and has since won numerous titles, including 17 Grand Slam singles titles, making him one of the most successful tennis players of all time. Nadal is known for his powerful topspin forehand and aggressive playing style, which has earned him the nickname "The King of Clay."

Roger Federer is a Swiss professional tennis player who is widely regarded as one of the greatest tennis players of all time. Born on August 8, 1981, in Basel, Switzerland, Federer began playing tennis at a young age and quickly rose through the junior ranks. He turned professional in 1998 and won his first Grand Slam title at the 2003 Australian Open. Since then, Federer has won 20 Grand Slam titles, including eight Wimbledon titles and six Australian Open titles. He has also held the number one ranking in the world for a record 310 weeks. Known for his elegant playing style and exceptional shot-making ability, Federer is often called the "King of Tennis."

Petra Cortright is a contemporary artist known for her digital artworks that often incorporate elements of collage, painting, and photography. Born in 1989 in California, Cortright studied at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena before launching her career as a full-time artist. Her works are characterized by their vibrant colors and layered compositions, often exploring themes of identity, technology, and popular culture. Cortright's work has been exhibited internationally, including at the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles.

Wolfgang Puck is an Austrian-born chef and restaurateur, known for his modern California cuisine. Born on July 8, 1949, in Klagenfurt, Austria, Puck grew up in a family of cooks and began his culinary career at the age of 14. He moved to France to attend culinary school, and later worked in several Michelin-starred restaurants in Paris and London before coming to the United States in 1973. Puck opened his first restaurant, Spago, in Los Angeles in 1982, which quickly gained critical acclaim and helped establish him as a leading figure in American cuisine. Today, Puck owns and operates numerous restaurants around the world, including Spago, CUT, and Wolfgang Puck Cafe. He has also made appearances on various TV shows and has written several cookbooks.

Christopher Nolan is a British-American film director, screenwriter, and producer. Born in London, England in 1970, Nolan grew up in a family of modest means. He developed an interest in filmmaking at an early age and pursued it throughout his education. After studying English Literature at University College London, Nolan began his career in the film industry as a screenwriter and later turned to directing. His breakthrough film, 'Memento,' released in 2000, gained critical acclaim and led to a series of successful movies such as 'Inception,' 'The Dark Knight Trilogy,' and 'Interstellar.' Nolan is known for his complex and thought-provoking storytelling, often exploring themes of identity, memory, and the human condition. He is widely regarded as one of the most innovative and influential filmmakers of his generation.

Jenny Holzer is an American artist known for her provocative and often controversial installations and projections of texts and images. Born in Gallipolis, Ohio in 1950, Holzer studied at the Rhode Island School of Design and later received her MFA from Yale University. Her work often engages with social and political issues such as war, violence, and power dynamics. Throughout her career, Holzer has created numerous public installations, including LED displays in major cities around the world, as well as sculptures and paintings. Her work has been exhibited widely in museums and galleries, and she has received numerous awards for her contributions to contemporary art.

Sol LeWitt was an American artist known for his minimalist artwork. Born in 1928, LeWitt studied at Syracuse University and later attended the Art Students League in New York City. Throughout his career, LeWitt explored various mediums including painting, drawing, sculpture, and printmaking, but it was his wall drawings and installations that gained him widespread recognition. His work often featured simple shapes such as lines, squares, and rectangles, arranged in complex patterns to create intricate compositions. LeWitt was a pioneer of Conceptual art movement and his work continues to influence contemporary artists today.

Zhang Yiming is a Chinese entrepreneur, investor, and philanthropist, born in 1981. He is the founder and CEO of ByteDance, a technology company that owns popular platforms such as TikTok, Helo, and Musical.ly. Zhang founded ByteDance in 2016 and has since expanded its reach globally, acquiring several media companies and investing in various startups. Zhang is also known for his philanthropic efforts, particularly in education, and has been recognized as one of China's most influential business leaders.

Robert John Downey Jr. was born in New York City on April 4, 1965, to actor father, Robert Downey Sr., and actress mother, Elsie Downey. After struggling with drug addiction in the 90's, Downey made a comeback in the late 90's and early 2000's, starting with his role in 'Ally McBeal,' followed by his breakout performance in 'Iron Man' (2008). Since then, Downey has starred in multiple successful movies such as 'The Avengers,' 'Iron Man 3,' 'The Judge,' and 'Sherlock Holmes.' Downey has been married twice, first to Deborah Falconi, and currently to Susan Downey. He has two sons, Indio and Exton.
